dt: {bc}relating to or given to crude bodily pleasures and appetites

dt.t: the superiority of the spiritual and eternal over the {wi}carnal{/wi}

pt: {sc}carnal{/sc} {sc}fleshly{/sc} {sc}sensual{/sc} {sc}animal{/sc} mean having a relation to the body. {sc}carnal{/sc} may mean only this but more often connotes derogatorily an action or manifestation of a person's lower nature.

pt.t: a saint who had experienced {it}fleshly{/it} temptations

pt: {sc}sensual{/sc} may apply to any gratification of a bodily desire or pleasure but commonly implies sexual appetite with absence of the spiritual or intellectual.
{sc}animal{/sc} stresses the physical as distinguished from the rational nature of a person.

et: Middle English, from Anglo-French or Late Latin; Anglo-French {it}carnel, charnel{/it}, from Late Latin {it}carnalis{/it}, from Latin {it}carn-, caro{/it} flesh; akin to Greek {it}keirein{/it} to cut {ma}{mat|shear|}{/ma}
shortdef: relating to or given to crude bodily pleasures and appetites
